title: How to Grow a Nepenthes

steps.headline: Welcome to the addiction.
steps.description: Chuck away the instructions if you got it from a garden centre that doesn't specialize in them. They are nearly always wrong. Also, if it says N.alata then it isn't. It is most likely N. x ventrata, a hybrid between N. alata and N. ventricosa.

steps.headline: Set up your Nepenthes' pot.
Water your Nepenthes.
steps.description: Distilled water is recommended but Nepenthes have a higher tolerance to hard water than other carnivorous plants.

steps.headline: Find out what kind of nepenthes you have by checking on wikipedia or something similar.
steps.description: There is a table with all the different species listed. Highland nepenthes and lowland nepenthes are a division of nepenthes.

steps.headline: Now you know what kind of nepenthes it is, check for special requirements, eg.
steps.description: misting or soil types. If you live in a climate that goes colder than 5ºC, keep highland nepenthes inside. If it goes below about 18ºC, keep lowland nepenthes inside. Most of the time, the mix it comes in is bogus unless you got it from somewhere that specializes in Nepenthes.

steps.headline: If you are repotting your Nepenthes, choose a soil mix.
steps.description: There are many, many, many soil mixes for Nepenthes, which one you choose is pure preference and experience as to which produces the best results. Orchid bark, perlite, pumice, peat, long-fibered sphagnum moss (be careful when buying this stuff, make sure it's real moss and not decorative), charcoal, tree-fern fiber, are all good ingredients. Be careful when repotting as the roots are delicate. One reason not to choose long-fibered sphagnum is because it tends to cling to the roots.

steps.headline: 'Determine whether your nepenthes is male or female.
steps.description: The flowers are either male or female, and they typically appear after the plant has made a climbing or scrambling vine. They don't change. If you find that it is in fact, for example, a male, then the next flower stalk is going to be male. It is a male plant. It can't be changed. Female flowers have a rather bulgy cit in the middle, whereas on the male flower is is thinner and yellow pollen is visible. To get an idea of this, look on Google images, there is a picture somewhere that shows the differences. On many of the carnivorous plant forums, there have been projects set up that let you trade pollen with other members of the forum, and when there are seeds, you get an equal share of them. An overall good idea.

steps.headline: Good luck!
steps.description: You WILL get addicted. when you do go over to terraforums.com and register. Introduce yourself and make sure you say where you got your first Nepenthes guide - on wikiHow! !

text:
Steps Welcome to the addiction. Chuck away the instructions if you got it from a garden centre that doesn't specialize in them. They are nearly always wrong. Also, if it says N.alata then it isn't. It is most likely N. x ventrata, a hybrid between N. alata and N. ventricosa. Set up your Nepenthes' pot. Get a tray, and put a regular plant pot in it, the right way up. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Grow-a-Nepenthes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Nepenthes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Grow-a-Nepenthes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Nepenthes-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Put the plant pot that your nepenthes is in on top of the plant pot in the tray. This lets water drain away, but not come back up into the pot. They don't like being soaked. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Grow-a-Nepenthes-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Grow-a-Nepenthes-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Grow-a-Nepenthes-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Grow-a-Nepenthes-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Water your Nepenthes. Distilled water is recommended but Nepenthes have a higher tolerance to hard water than other carnivorous plants. Find out what kind of nepenthes you have by checking on wikipedia or something similar. There is a table with all the different species listed. Highland nepenthes and lowland nepenthes are a division of nepenthes. Now you know what kind of nepenthes it is, check for special requirements, eg. misting or soil types. If you live in a climate that goes colder than 5ºC, keep highland nepenthes inside. If it goes below about 18ºC, keep lowland nepenthes inside. Most of the time, the mix it comes in is bogus unless you got it from somewhere that specializes in Nepenthes. Highland Nepenthes If you are repotting your Nepenthes, choose a soil mix. There are many, many, many soil mixes for Nepenthes, which one you choose is pure preference and experience as to which produces the best results. Orchid bark, perlite, pumice, peat, long-fibered sphagnum moss (be careful when buying this stuff, make sure it's real moss and not decorative), charcoal, tree-fern fiber, are all good ingredients. Be careful when repotting as the roots are delicate. One reason not to choose long-fibered sphagnum is because it tends to cling to the roots. 'Determine whether your nepenthes is male or female. The flowers are either male or female, and they typically appear after the plant has made a climbing or scrambling vine. They don't change. If you find that it is in fact, for example, a male, then the next flower stalk is going to be male. It is a male plant. It can't be changed. Female flowers have a rather bulgy cit in the middle, whereas on the male flower is is thinner and yellow pollen is visible. To get an idea of this, look on Google images, there is a picture somewhere that shows the differences. On many of the carnivorous plant forums, there have been projects set up that let you trade pollen with other members of the forum, and when there are seeds, you get an equal share of them. An overall good idea. Good luck! You WILL get addicted. when you do go over to terraforums.com and register. Introduce yourself and make sure you say where you got your first Nepenthes guide - on wikiHow! !
